title-group.article-title: On the Load–Unload (L–U) and Force–Release (F–R) Algorithms for Simulating Brittle Fracture Processes via Lattice Models

article-meta.aff: Computational Solid Mechanics Laboratory, Division of Physical Sciences and Engineering, King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s), 2011. Reprints and permissions: www.sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: General summaries on the load–unload and force–release methods indicate that the two methods are efficient for different-charactered quasi-static failures; therefore, it is important to choose the right one for different applications. Then we take, as an example, the case where the release of the ruptured element's internal force is infinitely slower than the relaxation of the lattice system and analyze why the force–release method works better than the load–unload method in this particular case. Different trial deformation fields are used by them to track the next equilibrium state. Force–release method ensures that the deformation throughout the whole failure process coincides exactly with the controlled-displacement boundary conditions and we utilize the ‘left modulus’ concept to prove that this method satisfies the energetic evolution in the force–displacement diagram; both of which are not satisfied by the load–unload method. To illustrate that the force–release method is not just another form of the load–unload method, a tensile test on a specifically designed system is analyzed to further compare the above two methods, showing that their predicted sequences of elemental failures can be different. In closing, we simulate the uniaxial tensile test on a beam lattice system by the load–unload and force–release methods and exploit the details of the resulting fracture processes.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Lattice models are generally divided into two categories: those simulating directly atomic lattices or materials whose internal structures are naturally lattice-like (Deshpande and Fleck, 2001; Deshpande et al., 2001; McKown et al., 2008; Queheillalt et al., 2008) and the ones used to model continuum systems in an equivalent manner (Bolander and Saito, 1998; Gao and Klein, 1998; Hansen and Roux, 2000; Krajcinovic and Vujosevic, 1998; van Mier et al., 2002; Liu et al., 2007). The latter have been successfully used to solve classical elastic problems (Hrennikoff, 1941). Then, such models have been employed for simulating the progressive failure in heterogeneous media, especially by theoretical physicists (Hansen and Roux, 2000; Herrmann and Roux, 1992). It has been shown that statistical lattice models offer a convenient framework to explore the evolution of damage associated with microcracks formation and growth (Delaplace et al., 1996; Hansen and Roux, 2000; Krajcinovic and Rinaldi, 2005; Krajcinovic and Vujosevic, 1998; Mastilovic and Krajcinovic, 1999; Rinaldi and Lai, 2007; Sahimi, 2000). Dynamic behaviors are also simulated (McKown et al., 2008) but they are not discussed in this study. Failure of particle composites has been frequently simulated using these models (Karihaloo et al., 2003; Liu et al., 2008b; Ostoja-Starzewski, 2002; van Mier et al., 2002). Liu et al. extended the lattice elements, i.e. beams and springs into a more general entity with the capability of including materials' heterogeneities in every single element (Liu et al., 2008a, 2010a ; Liu and Liang, 2009; Liu et al., 2009a,2009b, 2010b). More recently, lattice methods have been adopted as a quantitative approach to study the material properties and typical damage modes of polycrystalline microstructures such as ceramics in the small-deformation regime (Rinaldi et al., 2008; Rinaldi, 2009).

Since the lattice-type model seems promising for studying significant mechanical problems, it is worthy to explore its numerical implementation so that we may formulate more robust algorithms to make the model more accurate and reasonable. For this purpose, our attention is focused on analyzing and comparing the load–unload (L-U) (Bolander and Saito, 1998; Karihaloo et al., 2003; Ostoja-Starzewski, 2002; Rots et al., 2008) and force–release (F-R) method (Elias et al., 2010; Li et al., 2002; Liu, 2007; Liu et al., 2009b).

The L-U method can be summarized as follows (Herrmann and Roux, 1992; Karihaloo et al., 2003; Rinaldi and Lai, 2007; Rots et al., 2008; van Mier et al., 2002). It is notable that ‘unloading’ here does not mean plastic unloading but rather means the removal of external loadings elastically. Lattices are composed of linear-elastic line elements like bars or beams, among which for each a strength criterion is adopted. The load is applied gradually and a linear-elastic analysis is performed until the element with the highest stress-to-strength ratio reaches the prescribed threshold value. This particular element is then eliminated and a new analysis is performed. The stiffness matrix is updated while keeping the applied load unchanged to check whether another element will fail. If no more elements fail, the calculation is restarted from zero loads again until the specimen reached complete failure. The above procedure and strength criterion prevent the consideration of any non-linearities. Investigators have usually analyzed the curve after a smoothing operation as in the solid line in Figure 1 since the original load-deformation curve is hard to observe (Karihaloo et al., 2003; Lilliu and van Mier, 2003; Rinaldi and Lai, 2007). Figure 1.
A typical loading curve obtained by the L–U method. (Rinaldi and Lai, 2007).

When it comes to the F–R method (Elias et al., 2010; Li et al., 2002; Liu, 2007; Liu et al., 2009b), a trial displacement field is constructed to be compatible with the controlled-displacements all over the failure process including non-equilibrium processes between successive equilibrium states. The elemental internal forces to be released are regarded as static actions, which are supposed to release from the initial value to zero. Thus, based on the principle of superposition, the sequence of the induced failures can be continuously traced. The main characteristic of this method is that a series of forces to be released are applied in a straightforward manner to the system during the induced failure process without the need to introduce any explicit elemental stiffness evolution.
Naturally, one question arises: although the L–U and F–R methods are both used for quasi-static failures, what is the difference between them?

Before everything, features of quasi-static processes are recalled. Different from a real thermodynamic process, a quasi-static process is not continuous, but consists of a series of equilibrium states. Therefore, it is difficult for a quasi-static process to describe the real non-equilibrium process between successive equilibrium states. Unfortunately, under some fixed prescribed displacement loading, the avalanche-like failure process (Rinaldi and Lai, 2007) from the state in which the element corresponding to the 1st-order rupture begins to break up to the next state in which the element related to the nth-order rupture finishes breaking is just such a non-equilibrium process, assuming the avalanche is n-ordered. Therefore, to make it possible to deal with it in a quasi-static manner, necessary quasi-static assumptions have to be made.

Then, a general comparison is made from the viewpoint of characteristic time scales as follows (Bai et al., 2005; Rong et al., 2006). During the brittle fracture process of a lattice system, there are three characteristic times which play key roles in the non-equilibrium failure process between successive equilibrium states: the loading characteristic time of the external displacement loading, Tloading; the release characteristic time of internal forces of a ruptured element, Telem; and the relaxation characteristic time of the lattice system, Tlattice. Correspondingly, these are the following three main quasi-static cases:
Case 1. O(Tloading) ≫ O(Telem) ≫ O(Tlattice). Now, the release of the internal forces in ruptured elements is infinitely slower than the relaxation of the lattice. For example, suppose a lattice system in which each broken spring is connected in parallel with a dashpot whose viscosity coefficient is very large. In other words, such a slow release of ruptured elements' internal forces leads to a considerable dependence of failure processes on the elemental failure sequence. As we will show later, the F–R method works better than the L–U method in that case.
Case 2. O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ≫ O(Telem). The relaxation of the lattice is infinitely slower than the release of internal forces of ruptured elements. For example, suppose a lattice system has such a small damp that the kinetic energy converted from the elastic potential energy of the 1st ruptured element E1 is very slowly dissipated in the lattice system. Thus, the whole system experiences a very long oscillation, and the oscillating deformation causes the rupture of the second element E2. The elastic energy of element E2 is then converted to the kinetic energy of the system as well. Since the dissipation process is very slow, the kinetic energy converted by the successive ruptures of elements E1 and E2 is almost equal to the kinetic energy converted by the simultaneous ruptures of E1 and E2. Then, the new oscillating deformation causes the rupture of the third element E3, and so on. The non-equilibrium failure process (avalanche) proceeds until the rupture of element En. After that the oscillating deformation cannot induce any further rupture under the current prescribed displacement loading. Finally, the system gradually reaches the new equilibrium state. Briefly, when checking the occurrence of the nth-order rupture, elements E1, E2,… rupturing previously can be assumed to break simultaneously, so the elemental failure sequence is somehow neglected. Now, the L–U method is more accurate than the F–R method due to this particular physics feature.
Case 3. O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ∼ O(Telem). The relaxation of the lattice is approximately as quick as the release of the internal forces of ruptured elements. For this case, both the F–R and the L–U methods do not work well.

For the above analysis, we find that as long as the non-equilibrium process is not limited, one can adopt the quasi-static assumption that the release of ruptured elements' internal forces is infinitely slow or fast when compared to the relaxation of the lattice system. Therefore, comparisons between the L–U and F–R methods become meaningless without particular quasi-static assumptions.

To explore their distinctions in a straightforward manner, this article limits the discussion within the above ‘Case 1’. Recently in Elias et al. (2010), the F–R and L–U methods are shown to give different predictions in the non-proportional loading cases. However, in this study, we will show that even under proportional loading cases, they operate differently. The purpose here is not to argue which is right or wrong between L–U and F–R methods, but to show that these two methods are essentially different, providing a reminder that they should be chosen according to the physical features of the different failure processes. In the following, even though we sometimes say that the L–U method is less accurate than the F–R method, the purpose is only to facilitate the statements instead of criticizing the L–U method. Again, our purpose is mainly to explore their differences in a more explicit manner based on the above characteristic-time-scale analyses.

One assumption in the above L–U method is that the displacement-controlled failure process can be obtained via a damage-controlled simulation. Multiple ruptures can happen during so-called ‘avalanche’, where the stress redistribution caused by previous ruptured elements results in an increase in the degree of stress concentration in other elements causing their attainment of their strength limit prematurely. As a result, induced failures subsequently happen despite the external controlled displacement being kept constant. Rinaldi and Lai (2007) stated that in the L–U method, the induced failures are checked out in a force-controlled or equivalently damage-controlled manner. However, no proof has been found in the literature for the equivalence between damage-controlled and displacement-controlled loading conditions in the quasi-static case. In the damage-controlled condition, the force-displacement curve is constructed by a series of equilibrium states each of which corresponds to a failure ‘event’ during the failure process. From this perspective, the damage-controlled case is equivalent to the force-controlled case as both can capture the snap-back phenomenon (Yang and Proverbs, 2004). However, both should be different from the displacement-controlled case in which the curve can never snap back because the controlled-displacement cannot decrease. Actually, this equivalence is valid only under the above ‘case 2’, and invalid under ‘Case 1’. Further discussion about this topic is presented later in this article.

Furthermore, from the viewpoint of energy dissipation, a crack is produced by generating and extending a fracture surface free of actions, or rather by breaking interacting bonds between material particles (Gao and Klein, 1998). Before cracking, every pair of fracture surfaces is bonded together, or in other words, stores internal interactions, which are then released during the cracking process because free fracture surfaces indicate that there are no actions on them. Therefore, at least in a qualitative sense, the release of internal forces of ruptured elements corresponds to the formation and extension of free surfaces as well as the appearance of surface free energy that may be understood as the mechanical work done by the released forces. It will be demonstrated later that the F–R method theoretically satisfies the requirement that the area below the curve corresponds to the strain energy in the force–displacement diagram.

Last but not least, the L–U method takes the release as an event happening at a time point instead of a process. The critical element is eliminated and then a new linear analysis is conducted, suggesting that the internal forces in that element are totally and instantaneously released when reaching the strength limit. In other words, this method treats the release as an event happening at a point in time rather than being a process. As discussed in Liu et al. (2008a) and Liu and Liang (2009), in dynamic simulations, the counterpart of the internal force to be released is the inertial effect caused by the sudden appearance of non-zero accelerations in the vicinity of the ruptured element. Of course, in quasi-static cases with O(Tloading) ≫ O(Telem) ≫ O(Tlattice), we discard all kinds of inertial effects, but the reasonability of neglecting inertial influences should be guaranteed by the assumption that the internal forces of the ruptured elements are released in an infinitely slow sense, instead of a simultaneous event as the L–U method suggests.

In summary, the comparison is conducted in terms of: (1) Whether the trial displacement fields used to judge the existence of induced ruptures are coincident with the controlled-displacement boundary condition during the actually non-equilibrium process between successive equilibrium states. (2) Infinitely fast/slow release of ruptured elements' internal forces. The quasi-static assumption in the above ‘Case 1’ requires the release of the ruptured element's internal force to be infinitely slow, however, the L–U method indicates that the releasing process is infinitely fast (by setting the stiffness of critical elements to zero once the strength limit is reached).

This article is organized as follows. In Section L–U Method, the L–U method is revisited with emphasis on the aforementioned issues. In Section F–R Method, we present the F–R method followed by a specifically designed example illustrating the difference in the failure sequence predicted by the aforementioned two methods in Section A Specially–Designed Example. In Section Numerical Example and Analysis, numerical examples are conducted to demonstrate the performance of the F–R and L–U methods. Conclusions drawn from the above examples are presented in Section Conclusions.

sec.title: L–U METHOD
sec.p:
The formulation of the L–U method suitable for cases O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ≫ O(Telem) is provided here in order to facilitate further discussions. Without loss of generality, a bar-lattice system is chosen where the bar can only sustain tensile/compressive loadings. Under quasi-static monotonic increasing controlled displacement ū as shown in Figure 2 and as the load reaches the value ū0, element E1 reaches its strength limit sE1 and needs to be eliminated. The displacement field at this moment is denoted as D0 and E1's internal force is denoted as FE1. E1 is deleted from the lattice system and the updated system's external controlled displacement ū0 is applied to check whether other element(s) would fail. The trial displacement field under these conditions is denoted as D. From this point forward, we will call the first-induced elemental failure ‘1st-order induced failure’. Figure 2.
Boundary and loading conditions for a displacement-controlled tensile test on a lattice.

In order to determine the relationship between D and D0, an equivalent transformation is made as follows. The contribution of element E1 to the rest of the system is to apply a force, FE1, at both of its ends with opposed directions. Apparently, E1 is eliminated from the system while keeping its actions active. The left system will exactly keep the same deformation state as before removing E1, as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Two equivalent forms of the same displacement field D0.

Thus, if there are no more elements reaching their strength limit at the load level ū0, the following relationship with the help of Figure 4 applies (1)D=D0+ΔD1 where ΔD1 is obtained under the loading conditions shown in the very right part of Figure 4 and D the final equilibrium state corresponding to the load level ū0. Figure 4.
Relationship among deforming fields based on the principle of superposition.

However, if another element E2 has exceeded its strength limit in D, it indicates that this element reached its strength limit sE2 when the load on the updated system has become xu¯0 (0 < x < 1), or rather under the corresponding deforming field (2)D=x(D0+ΔD1)=xD0+xΔD1 It is worth noting that x in Equation (2) does not mean the share of rupture element's internal force having released. Instead, the smaller x one element has, the bigger possibility for this element to break next. As discussed in the introduction, the L–U method allows the total and instant release of elemental internal forces once elements begin breaking because O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ≫ O(Telem). In principle, of course, it fails to capture the process where the release of elemental internal forces is infinitely slow.

The illustration provided by Rinaldi and Lai (2007) for the process of ‘avalanche’, as shown in Figure 5 helps in understanding Equation (2). Here, an avalanche means a cascade of ruptures of more than one link in correspondence to the same controlled-displacement value in the displacement-controlled process. It is an instability phenomenon occurring when the new equilibrated lattice configuration in Equation (1), which is reached after the first rupture of E1, is kinematically admissible but incompatible with the lattice strength. From this point of view, the existing L–U method takes for granted that the displacement-controlled loading curve can be obtained by smoothening the curve given by the corresponding damage-controlled experiment. Figure 5.
Idea of L–U method on induced failures (Rinaldi and Lai, 2007).

However, the subtlety is that the configuration x(D0 + ΔD1) can never appear in the actual displacement-controlled experiment. This is explained as follows. We argue that in the actual physical process, the contribution of controlled displacement to the total deformation, i.e. the first term xD0 in the right side of Equation (2) is constant because the controlled displacement stays unchanged as u¯0; therefore, it is not supposed to be adjusted by the factor x as in Equation (2). In comparison, the second item xΔD1 seems reasonable because it represents how easily the induced failure happens under the influence of previous ruptures. On the other hand, however, it is a must to let both D0 and △D1 simultaneously be adjusted by x when O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ≫ O(Telem), which means the rupture element's internal force will be released totally and instantaneously once the element breaks.

Based on the above analysis, when O(Tloading) ≫ O(Telem) ≫ O(Tlattice) instead, rather than Equation (2), a more accurate form of the trial displacement field D to judge the existence of induced failure should be expressed as (3)D=D0+λΔD1 (0<λ<1) because now the ruptured element's internal force will be released from the initial value to zero in an infinitely slow manner, which leads to the discussion in Section F–R Method.

sec.title: Formulation
sec.p:
This method is developed by tracing the release process of internal forces of ruptured elements under the quasi-static assumption O(Tloading) ≫ O(Telem) ≫ O(Tlattice) (Li et al., 2002; Liu, 2007; Liu et al., 2009b). Honestly, the concept of force-releasing operation has a long history, nevertheless a detailed multi-stage release version is developed firstly by Liu (2007). Following the example studied in Section L–U Method, a new way to construct the trial displacement field is introduced based on the principle of superposition (Fung, 1993). According to the discussion in Section L–U Method regarding Figure 4, we delete E1 but keep its initial action on the system; the left system will remain unchanged. In other words, the contribution of E1 in D0 is equivalent to the pair of actions denoted by the red arrows in Figure 3. Once E1 reaches its strength limit, the process of having it deleted can be considered as the decrease of the red actions in Figure 3 from FE1 to 0. Here, for the sake of computational convenience, we implement it in a different way: as shown in Figure 6, we keep the red actions unchanged as FE1 and apply a new pair of actions (labeled as green arrows) on the system at both ends of E1. Figure 6.
Displacement field D = D0 + λ△D1, where λFE1 is the part already released among the initial value FE1.

Thus, another equivalent relation appears—the decrease of the red action pair from FE1 to 0 corresponds to the increase of the green action pair from 0 to FE1. Both correspond to the same process, namely the stress redistribution due to the release of E1's internal force. The resultant action of the green and red pairs is the amount of E1's internal force remaining to be released. The displacement field in the above releasing process of E1's internal force FE1 can be summarized in Equation (3). Here, λ has a robust physical meaning, namely the degree to which E1's internal force has been released; λ = 1 corresponds to the force being released completely. Let λ1 denote the exact value when the 1st-order induced element E2 reaches its strength limit. At this moment, E2's internal force is noted as FE2, and correspondingly we have
The displacement field: D1 = D0 + λ1ΔD1
The force to be released at E1's ends: (1 − λ1)FE1
The force to be released at E2's ends: FE2 The next task is to check whether another element would be induced to fail due to the release of both (1 − λ1)FE1 at E1's ends and FE2 at E2's ends. The trial displacement field is, (4)D=D1+λΔD2=D0+λ1ΔD1+λΔD2 (0<λ<1) where ΔD2 is calculated as in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Boundary and loading conditions for obtaining △D2.

The appearance of further induced failure, i.e. the 2nd order induced failure, indicates that there exists a special value, λ2, at which 2nd order induced failure happens in element E3, and we have,
The displacement field: (5)D2=D0+λ1ΔD1+λ2ΔD2
Force to be released at E1's ends: (1 − λ2)[(1 − λ1) FE1] = (1 − λ1)(1 − λ2) FE1
Force to be released at E2's ends: (1 − λ2) FE2
Force to be released at E3's ends: FE3

When the ith-order induced failure happens, we would have the following:
The displacement field: (6)Di=D0+∑k=1 iλkΔDk
The force to be released at E1's ends: (7)
The force to be released at E2's ends: (8)
…
The force to be released at Ei's ends: (9)
The force to be released at E(i + 1)'s ends: FE(i+1). Assuming the total number of induced failures is n − 1, then after the appearance of the (n − 1)th-order induced failure in element En, the field will be driven by the forces left to be released in E1, E2,…, En to the final equilibrium state corresponding to the loading level ū0. In this final state, the factor adjusting the field increment ΔDn is equal to 1, i.e., λn = 1, indicating no more induced failure would happen. Hence,
The final equilibrium displacement field admissible in both the kinematic and strength conditions: (10)Dfinal=D0+∑i=1 n-1λiΔDi+ΔDn
The force to be released at E1's ends: (11)
The force to be released at E2's ends: (12)
…
The force to be released at Ei's ends: (13)
…
The force to be released at En's ends: (14)
From above, we can see that all the elements ruptured at the level ū0 have totally released their internal forces in Dfinal as they are all to be multiplied by the factor 1 − λn, which is equal to 0.

sec.title: Comparison with the L–U Method
sec.p:
From the above statements, when compared with the L–U method presented in Section L–U Method, we can list five characteristics of the F–R method as follows:
The proposed F–R method is compatible with the controlled displacement throughout the loading process including the actually non-equilibrium processes between successive equilibrium states. Also, the induced failure is decided based on the field Di=D0+∑k=1 iλkΔDk. In the first term D0, the displacement on the controlled-displacement boundary is equal to ū0. In the second term ∑k=1 iλkΔDk, the displacement on the same boundary is zero by referring to Figures 4 and 7. Hence, in the field Di (1 ≤ i ≤ n), the displacement on the boundary is ū0, which stays constant during the whole process of force release. However, the L–U method lacks this characteristic as shown in Figure 5. Although it is not enough to say that the L–U method is wrong due to this incompatibility because of the non-equilibrium nature of the induced failure process, we at least have found a considerable difference between the trial deformation fields they adopt.
A release process of the ruptured elements' internal forces during the induced failure period is provided. For example, if the element Ei is induced to fail, its force releasing process is marked by a series of discrete points: FEi,(1 − λi)FEi, (1 − λi)(1 − λi+1)FEi, (1 − λi)(1 − λi+1)(1 − λi+2)FEi,…, (1 − λi)(1 − λi+1)…(1 − λn−1)FEi, 0. The evolution of this process progressing through these discrete values is driven by the appearances of the subsequent induced failures, namely E(i+1), E(i+2),…, En. As discussed in Section Introduction, infinitely slow release is required by the quasi-static assumption. In this sense, the F–R method allows for a gradual release of the internal forces mimicking a static force and, therefore, satisfies the quasi-static assumption O(Tloading) ≫ O(Telem) ≫ O(Tlattice). Furthermore, the F–R method takes into account the fact that the specimen keeps changing in the induced failure sense due to damage evolution. For example, FEi is acting on the system in which the ruptured elements are E1∼Ei, (1 − λi)FEi is acting on the system with the ruptured elements E1∼E(i + 1), and so on. However, the L–U method releases the total internal force of ruptured elements totally and instantaneously once they reach the strength limit, indicating an infinitely fast release. During one fixed non-equilibrium process between two successive processes, at every time point, the internal forces of elements which have reached their strength limits are simultaneously released, leading to the absence of influence due to elemental failure sequence. This embodies in details two methods' difference in releasing ruptured elements' internal forces, mentioned in the Section Introduction.
The directions along which the new equilibrium state is reached are different. In the L–U method, the next equilibrium state is reached from the origin of the force–displacement curve every time a new elemental failure appears, as shown in Figure 5. However, in the F–R method, the search starts from the last equilibrium state, and then goes on continuously along with the release of internal forces. On this particular point, F–R is indeed more robust because it guarantees a continuous evolution when compared with frequent sudden shifts between the last equilibrium state and the origin in the L–U method. The quasi-static assumption in ‘Case 1’ enables us to take the internal forces to be released as static forces, and therefore to continuously update the deformation field based on the principle of superposition as done in Equation (6).
In F–R method, an implicit degradation in stiffness has been automatically included along with the release process. This is explained as follows: for the induced element Ei, immediately after its rupture, the force to be released is FEi, which means that the ruptured element Ei can still store an internal force with the value FEi. Then, right after the start of failure in E(i + 1), the force to be released in Ei becomes (1 − λi)FEi, or equivalently, this force is left to be sustained by Ei, which requires Ei to have the ability to provide the relative bearing capability of loading, i.e. stiffness. Right after the appearance of En in the current configuration, Ei should have the stiffness to bear the current actions to be released, i.e. (1 − λi)(1 − λi+1)… (1 − λn−1)FEi. The hidden ‘stiffness’ of the ruptured element is automatically determined by requiring the system to stay in an equilibrium state throughout the induced process. In contrast to the common concept of stiffness, here ‘stiffness’ has to keep decreasing until it reaches zero, namely the internal forces of the ruptured element have to be completely released before further increase in the controlled displacement. However, F–R seems promising in simulating gradual degradation of every single element as long as we introduce the concept of ‘partial elemental failure’ into the current F–R algorithm. Namely, after releasing λiFEi in element Ei, for example, we assume the rest of this element stays ‘alive’, and transfer the left force (1 − λi)FEi back to an explicit stiffness for sustaining further deformation. The calculation of the left stiffness will be discussed in Section Energetic Viewpoint.
Instability is embodied by forces to be released in the system. It is evident that the vertical fall of load in the force–displacement curve indicates some sort of instability. Since each step during this failing process has been guaranteed an equilibrium state, how does the instability appear? For example, as shown in Figure 7 as well as Equation (7), there is a series of elemental internal forces to be released, which will keep pushing the system to new states automatically even though the external loading level is kept constant. This self-driven phenomenon is easily understood as an instability. When it comes to the L–U method, however, the instability can only be embodied by x < 1 in Equation (2), no apparent actions can be found to act as the self-driving forces.

sec.title: Energetic Viewpoint
sec.p:
The force–displacement diagram obtained by the F–R method shows a clear evolution process of the energy stored in the lattice. Here, we demonstrate the energy evolution driven by the F–R method by a simple one-dimensional (1D) example. A brittle bar is composed of three link elements, as shown in Figure 8(a). Figure 8.
1D example for demonstrating the energy evolution in the F–R method.

These three elements have the same section-area A, length L, and Young's modulus E, but different tensile strengths s, i.e. sE1 : sE2 : sE3=2:1:2. A quasi-static displacement-controlled tensile experiment is conducted on the bar. Obviously, element E2 will fail first among all three elements. At the moment E2 reaches its strength limit, note the reaction force at the loading end as F¯. It is evident that the internal forces in the three elements are all also F¯. At this moment, the system with three intact elements stays at the point A in the load–displacement diagram as shown in Figure 9, while the strain energy is (15)eA=12F¯u¯0 Figure 9.
Force–displacement curve for the one-dimensional example.

Afterwards, E2's internal force begins its release. For this special example, as shown in Figure 8(b), the reaction force at the loading point is (1-λ)F¯ when λF¯ among E2's initial force F¯ has been released. With the help of F¯=EAu¯03L, and the consideration that E1 and E3 are still intact elements, the strain in E1 and E3 is (16)ɛE1=ɛE3=(1-λ)F¯EA=(1-λ)u¯03L Therefore, the strain energy stored in E1 and E3 is (17)eE1+eE3=E[(1-λ)F¯EA]2AL=13F¯u¯0(1-λ)2=23eA(1-λ)2 by, again, using the fact F¯=EAu¯03L.

Then we thoroughly demonstrate the calculation of E2's strain energy. The reaction force at the loading point is (1-λ)F¯, which indicates the ‘partly-ruptured’ element E2 is sustaining an internal tensile force (1-λ)F¯. However, it is not possible to calculate the strain in E2 by this force value because now the degraded Young's modulus in E2 is unknown, but it can still be calculated from a different viewpoint. When the controlled displacement stays unchanged as u¯0, the total length of the deformed bar which is equal to the sum of three elements' current lengths should also stay unchanged; therefore, we have (18)3L+u¯0=2L(1+ɛE1)+L(1+ɛE2) From Equation (18) which we can get the strain of partially degraded E2 is (19)ɛE2=u¯03L+2λu¯03L=(1+2λ)u¯03L Therefore, the left modulus in E2 is (20)Eleft=(1-λ)F¯AɛE2 The concept of ‘left modulus’ is introduced here in a different way, namely by tracing the internal force left to be released. With the help of Equations (19) and (20), the strain energy in E2 is (21)eE2=12Eleftɛ2AL=13eA(1+λ-2λ2)

Finally, by combining Equations (17) and (21), we obtain a strain energy of the whole system corresponding to the value λ marked by point B in Figure 9 of the form (22)e=eE1+eE2+eE3=(1-λ)eA, which is exactly equal to the area of the shadowed triangle, coinciding totally with our usual sense regarding the force–displacement curve: the area under the loading curve is equal to the strain energy in the system under controlled-displacement conditions in the force–displacement diagram. Referring to Figure 1, the L–U method lacks this feature. Once more, it is emphasized here that such a reasonable energy evolution is guaranteed by the introduction of the ‘left modulus’ defined as Equation (20).

sec.title: A SPECIALLY-DESIGNED EXAMPLE
sec.p: Despite the differences between the F–R and the L–U methods listed in Section F–R Method, people can still misconstrue the F–R method for just another form of the L–U method, or rather these two methods are equivalent in nature. As mentioned in Section Introduction, their difference can only be expected to appear when induced failure happens.

Therefore, the example in Figure 10 is designed to show that different-induced failure sequences can result from the L–U and F–R methods. The parts of interest are bars E1, E2, and E3, which are installed through hinge links onto the left part of lattice-bar system. These three bars are linearly elastic with critical tensile strengths. Figure 10.
A specifically-designed tensile test to show the difference(s) between the L–U and F–R methods.

All bars in the lattice have the same Young's modulus E = 2.5 GPa and the same cross-sectional area A=310m2. The three bars of interest are of length 3L, while all the other bars are L=310m . The system is under uniaxial tension in a displacement-controlled manner. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that the following result is not sensitive to the above parameters.

When the controlled displacement u¯ increases to some special value, for example u¯0=L103, E1's internal force reaches its strength limit before both E2 and E3. Predictions of the L–U and F–R methods are provided as follows, respectively.

For the L–U method, E1 is deleted and therefore its stiffness becomes zero immediately after its rupture. A new linear analysis is then conducted, therefore, the updated trial field is x(D0 + ΔD1), where x depends on how easily the induced failure happens. However, during the release process of E1's internal force FE1, the ratio of E2's internal force to E3's is independent of the value of x and should be a constant, i.e., (23)rσ=FE2FE3=c which is equal to 9077.54N8213.02N=1.105, where 8213.02 and 9077.54N are the internal forces of E2 and E3, respectively, in the deformation field D0 + ΔD1. The physical background for a constant rσ is the quasi-static assumption O(Tloading) ≫ O(Tlattice) ≫ O(Telem).

For the F–R method, however, the ratio rσ depends on the degree to which the forceFE1 has been released, or in other words the state D = D0 + λΔD1 (0 < λ < 1) depends on how easily the induced failure happens. E1's stiffness decreases along with the increase of λ. Hence, (24)rσ=FE2FE3=rσ(λ) and we have rσ(λ) ≤ c where ‘=’ appears only when λ = 1. The curve of rσ(λ) ∼ λ is shown in Figure 11, where it is notable that the F–R curve is not a linear function even though it appears so. The aim of Figure 11 is to demonstrate that the L–U trial displacement field actually stays at a fixed state D0 + ΔD1, while the F–R field changes along with the force–releasing factor λ. Figure 11.
Different changes in the stress ratio of the L–U and F–R methods during the release process of E1's internal force.

Let sE2 and sE3 be the strength limits of E2 and E3, respectively. Without loss of generality, assume that (25)sE2=sE3=s When λ = 0, and based on the fact that E1 fails before E2 and E3, s is supposed to have a value larger than the internal forces of both E2 = 6818.20N and E3 = 7751.02N, or rather, s > 7751.02N.
In the L–U method, with the aid of Equation (23), when σE2 = s there is σE3 < s, which indicates that E2 reaches its strength limit before E3 does during the release process of E1's internal force.

The outcome is different in the F–R method. Now, rσ=FE2FE3 increases from the initial value rσ(λ=0)=6818.20N7751.02N=0.880, which is calculated before E1's rupture, to c = 1.105, along with the release of E1's internal force as shown in Figure 11 until either E2 or E3 are induced to reach their strength limits. Figure 12 shows the changes in the internal forces of both E2 and E3 during the process, which are two linear functions of λ. These two straight lines intersect with each other when λ = 0.519, and FE2 = FE3 = Fc = 7990.80N. According to Figure 12, the predictions of the F–R method take the following form (26){s<FcE3 fails before E2.s=Fcfail simultaneously.s>FcE2 fails before E3. Figure 12.
Internal force evolutions in E2 and E3 in E1's rupturing process predicted by the F–R method.

From the above analyses, and recalling that the L–U method predicts the failure of E2 before E3, the difference between the L–U and F–R methods is expected to arise when either s < Fc or s = Fc. More specifically, the induced failure sequence can vary due to the adopted method. We argue that this sequential difference can sometimes lead to very different subsequent fracture processes, especially when the system is much more complex than that is shown in Figure 10.

Additionally, if s > max {8213.02N, 9077.54N} indicating that neither E2 nor E3 has failed when λ = 1. In that case, when the increase in the external controlled displacement resumes, rσ(λ) keeps the unchanged value rσ(λ = 1) = c = 1.105 until further elemental failure happens.

sec.title: NUMERICAL EXAMPLE AND ANALYSIS
sec.p:
We study the failure patterns of the beam lattice as shown in Figure 13 under external quasi-static tensile controlled displacement by both the L–U and F–R methods, respectively. The beam lattice presented here is employed to describe the microstructures in particle composites such as concrete (Karihaloo et al., 2003; Liu et al., 2007, 2008b). The lattice material properties are listed in Table 1. Figure 13.
Composite panel specimen described by GB lattice model. Table 1.
The micro-elastic and strength properties of phases.
Phases E (MPa) ft (MPa)
Aggregate 70,000 100.0
Interface 25,000 1.875
Matrix 25,000 5.0

Figure 14 shows the force–displacement curves for both methods, while Figure 15 the change of the reaction force versus the accumulated-induced elemental failure number immediately after the peak load. Figures 16 and 17 show the final failure patterns obtained by the two methods. Figure 14.
Force–displacement curves obtained, respectively, by the L–U and F–R methods. Figure 15.
Reaction force vs accumulated elemental failure number during the fall right following the peak load. Figure 16.
Failure pattern predicted by the L–U method when u¯=1.0mm. Figure 17.
Failure pattern predicted by the F–R method when u¯=1.0mm.

No differences arise during the pre-peak regime. The two methods predict the same peak load, 6.819 × 106N, however, this characteristic is not general. In total, 10 specimens with different particle distributions have been simulated, among which four show differences between the peak load values obtained by the two methods. During the pre-peak regime, it is found that the higher the induced failure order is, the more possibly the peak loads become different. This is because the difference between the two methods completely lies in their different formulation to detect and deal with the induced failures. If no induced failure happens in the pre-peak regime, the L–U Equation (2) when x = 1 becomes the same as the F–R Equation (3) when λ = 1. This is the internal reason for the same pre-peak response.

Usually, a sudden drop in load follows immediately after the peak load (Karihaloo et al., 2003) and corresponds to an induced failure process with a considerable induced order. During this drop, the fracture patterns predicted by the two methods become increasingly different as more and more induced elemental failures consequentially appear due to the likelihood they would give different induced failure sequences as discussed in Section A Specially–Designed Example. Figures 16 and 17 are representative of the different induced failure sequences. In the F–R method, the load keeps decreasing in a stable fashion during the induced failure process driven by the release of the internal forces of the increasing ruptured elements. On the other hand, the reaction force from the L–U method exhibits strong vibrations. Despite the use of controlled-displacement condition, vibrations arise which is indicative of the hypothesis that this is purely a virtual phenomenon caused by the L–U method itself.

Generally, post-peak feathers become very different. For example, when the controlled displacement is 1.0mm, the total number of failures is 310 for the L–U method and 285 for the F–R method. The failure patterns at this loading level obviously depend on the method used as shown in Figures 16 and 17.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: This article discusses the applicability of two methods, namely the L–U and F–R methods for simulating quasi-static failures.

First, we conclude briefly that the L–U method works well when the release of ruptured elements' internal forces is infinitely faster than the relaxation of the lattice system, while the F–R method is more accurate if the release of ruptured elements' internal forces is infinitely slower than the lattice relaxation.

Even though the above is the general conclusion, detailed comparison has rarely been found from the literature except Elias et al. (2010). Unfortunately, Elias et al. (2010) have not analyzed this issue from a physical background, namely the characteristic time scales in the failure process.

To demonstrate the differences between the L–U and F–R methods in a straightforward manner, we analyze thoroughly why the F–R method works better than the L–U method in the particular case when the release of ruptured elements' internal forces is infinitely slow. Our purpose is not to criticize one and applaud the other, but to remind the readers of their considerable distinctions. Throughout the analysis, we frequently indicate that the relationship between Telem and Tlattice is the standard to judge which is appropriate for different physical processes. Differences found are summarized as follows:
Different trial displacement fields are used to track the successive-induced elemental failures as well as the upcoming equilibrium state. The F–R method guarantees that the deformation evolution keeps compatible with the controlled-displacement loadings all over the non-equilibrium process between successive equilibrium states. Although the lack of such a compatible feature in the L–U method is not an assured ground of condemnation because of the non-equilibrium nature, at least their different numerical operations have been explored.
Different quasi-static features are shown in the force–displacement curve. The F–R method ensures the area under the curve to be the exact amount of work done by external loadings and released forces. While the L–U method shows a snap-back phenomenon. Actually, the hidden physics meaning is that in the F–R method the ruptured elements' internal forces are released from initial values to zero infinitely slowly, but in the L–U method forces in ruptured elements are released totally, simultaneously and instantly once elements break. In one word, both F–R and L–U methods are techniques to figure out successive equilibrium states. Relationship between characteristic time scales determines their different manners to release ruptured elements' internal forces, consequently different forms of trial displacement fields, as shown respectively in Equations (2) and (6), and finally different failure behaviors.

fn.p: Figures 3, 4, 6, 7 and 11–17 appear in color online: ijd.sagepub.com

The authors show their great appreciation to the reviewers, especially the one who indicated the analysis from the viewpoint of characteristic time scales in his/her reviewing comments, which led to the improvement of this article.
